Subjective: Spot on neck x2 weeks. Onset after shaving or possible insect bite; initially thought it was a wart. Describes intermittent scabbing, swelling, redness, and itching. No pain. PMH: Warts, ear abscess. FH: Paternal side with sun-related skin problems (grandfather/uncles). No other similar spots on body. Social: Not mentioned. ICE: Concern for skin cancer ('serious form') after online search; wants lesion removed, prefers freezing.
Objective: Skin: Raised, pinkish-red lesion on neck, approx. 0.5 cm, with a redder spot in the center. No visible scab or flaking at time of exam. Dermoscopy performed. Neck: No other suspicious lesions noted, some freckles present. Lymph: No cervical lymphadenopathy on palpation.
Assessment: Undifferentiated skin lesion, neck. Differential diagnosis includes pyogenic granuloma vs. atypical mole. Awaiting specialist opinion.
Plan: 1. Diagnostics: Teledermatology consultation; photo to be sent to dermatologist for review. 2. Treatment: Plan pending dermatologist advice. Discussed potential removal options: cryotherapy, excision, or curettage. 3. Follow-up: Will call patient on Friday (before 10 am or after 3 pm) with dermatologist's recommendation. 4. Other: Advised to schedule a separate appointment for unrelated knee pain.
